item.title: Pressured by Trump, Mexico Sends 37 Accused Criminals to U.S.
item.description: Mexico has sought to do more to combat its cartels in an effort to stave off airstrikes threatened by President Trump.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mexican police officers at a crime scene in Culiacán, the home territory of the Sinaloa cartel, in 2024.

item.title: Carney Speech on U.S. ‘Rupture’ and Canada’s Survival Draws Standing Ovation at Davos
item.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney got a standing ovation in Davos for starkly describing the end of Pax Americana. He is looking for new allies to help his country survive it.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Ian Austen

item.title: C.I.A.’s New Focus on Latin America Reflected in Raid to Seize Maduro
item.description: A senior U.S. official declined to confirm the specific operations in Venezuela, but said a covert team provided real-time support for the military.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Tyler Pager
item.media:description: A member of Venezuela’s National Guard at the entrance to the country’s largest military complex in Caracas, the capital, after President Nicolás Maduro’s capture on Jan. 3.

item.title: The Northern Lights Have Inspired Humans for Thousands of Years
item.description: The aurora borealis has animated myths, art, poetry and music for thousands of years. Here are some examples.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:credit: Heritage Art/Heritage Images, via Getty Images
item.media:description: “Aurora Borealis,” an 1865 painting by the American landscape painter Frederic Edwin Church.

item.title: A Venezuelan Political Prisoner Finally Comes Home
item.description: Ángel Godoy was thrown into jail after writing columns that angered the government of President Nicolás Maduro. Now his family is trying to make up for lost time.
item.dc:creator: Alejandro Cegarra, Isayen Herrera and James Wagner
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ángel Godoy embracing his wife, Adriana Briceño, after arriving at home for the first time after spending a year in jail.

item.title: How Trump Flexes Power in White House Meetings With Zelensky and Others
item.description: With cameras rolling, President Trump met with more than 40 international leaders in his first year back in office.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater

item.title: Death Toll Rises in Guatemalan Gang Riots
item.description: Uprisings in three prisons have killed 10 police officers, presenting another challenge for President Bernardo Arévalo in his fight against corruption and organized crime.
item.dc:creator: Jody García, James Wagner and Daniele Volpe
item.media:credit: Daniele Volpe for The New York Times
item.media:description: A ceremony to honor eight police officers who died in attacks by gang members the day before, on Monday in Guatemala City.

item.title: Splits Emerge Among Venezuelans as Revolutionary Dream Fades
item.description: Supporters of former president Hugo Chávez, the anti-American socialist, are struggling to come to terms with their government’s pact with Washington.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib
item.media:description: Demonstrators demanding the release of President Nicolás Maduro in Caracas, Venezuela, on Friday.

item.title: What to Know About Hezbollah’s Ties to Venezuela
item.description: U.S. authorities have accused Hezbollah of complicity in drug trafficking and money laundering schemes in Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hezbollah fighters at the Lebanon-Syria border in 2017.

item.title: Guatemala Declares State of Emergency to Address Gang Violence
item.description: The country has seen a surge of unrest in recent days, including uprisings at prisons and the killing of police officers, which the authorities have blamed on gangs.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Guatemalan riot police officers guard the entrance to the men’s Preventive Detention Center in Guatemala City on Sunday.

item.title: Chile Wildfires Kill 16 and Force Wide Evacuation
item.description: One mayor pleaded with the national government for help as flames destroyed entire neighborhoods in the southern region of Biobío.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and John Bartlett
item.media:description: Buildings damaged by wildfires in Chile’s Biobío region on Sunday.

item.title: The Biggest Challenge in Venezuela Is Soaring Food Prices
item.description: Economic instability in Venezuela after the U.S. raid to capture its president is deepening inflation and rattling the currency, sending grocery bills soaring for millions of people.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova, Camille Rodríguez Montilla and Isayen Herrera
item.media:description: A woman showing her nearly empty refrigerator in Los Teques, Venezuela.

item.title: Mr. Carney Goes to Beijing
item.description: The trip, a whirlwind of meetings with Chinese industry and top government officials, conveyed how the prime minister is viewing the wider world.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Carney with Xi Jinping, China’s top leader.

item.title: Can Cuba Survive Without Venezuela’s Oil?
item.description: President Trump stopped Venezuelan oil shipments to Cuba, and experts say disaster looms. Oil fuels its electric grid and without alternative supplies the country will plunge into extended darkness.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles
item.media:description: A Cuban-flagged oil tanker anchored near the Matanzas terminal this month in Cuba.

item.title: Trump Has Machado’s Nobel Prize, but Neither Got What They Really Wanted
item.description: President Trump has María Corina Machado’s medal, but he is not recognized as the prize laureate. Ms. Machado did not win Mr. Trump’s endorsement to become Venezuela’s president.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: María Corina Machado’s decision to present her Nobel Peace Prize medal to President Trump has been met with mixed reviews in the United States and abroad.

item.title: Judge Recommends U.S. Issue Visa to Student Who Was Deported in Error
item.description: A federal prosecutor apologized this week, saying an ICE officer made a “mistake” in deporting Any Lucia López Belloza, a college freshman in Massachusetts, to Honduras.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Any Lucia Lopez Belloza's attorney, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Any Lucia López Belloza celebrating her high school graduation in Texas last year. She was attending college in Massachusetts before her deportation in November.

item.title: Julio Iglesias Denies Sexual Abuse Claims by Former Employees
item.description: The singer called the accusations “completely false” in a statement released after Spanish prosecutors said they would investigate.
item.dc:creator: Aimee Ortiz
item.media:description: Julio Iglesias in 2016, when a star bearing his name was unveiled in San Juan, P.R.

item.title: C.I.A. Director Meets With Venezuela’s Interim President in Caracas
item.description: The high-profile visit, which could be seen as snubbing the opposition, comes nearly two weeks after the U.S. military seized President Nicolás Maduro in a raid.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: John Ratcliffe, the C.I.A. director, at the U.S. Capitol last week. On Thursday, he met with Delcy Rodríguez, the interim president of Venezuela, and delivered a message of cooperation.

item.title: After Trump Call, Colombia’s Petro Turns Up Heat on Far-Left Armed Group
item.description: President Gustavo Petro of Colombia is taking a harder line against the National Liberation Army, or ELN, a leftist group experts call a powerful drug trafficker in Colombia and Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal, Genevieve Glatsky and Max Bearak
item.media:description: National Liberation Army, or ELN, rebels in the Catatumbo region of Colombia last year.

item.title: Canada Strikes Tariffs Deal With China, as Carney Looks to Diversify From U.S.
item.description: China will in turn cut its own tariffs on Canadian canola products, Prime Minister Mark Carney of Canada said in Beijing on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Carney of Canada meeting on Friday with Xi Jinping, China’s leader, at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing.

item.title: Trump Chooses Venezuela’s Oil Over Democracy
item.description: Two conversations this week confirmed that President Trump backs the remnants of Nicolás Maduro’s regime over the Venezuelan opposition seeking to hold elections.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:description: Delcy Rodríguez, the interim president of Venezuela, moments before her swearing-in in Caracas, the country’s capital, in January.

item.title: Venezuela’s Interim Leader Delivers State of the Union Address
item.description: In her State of the Union address, Delcy Rodríguez echoed her predecessors’ fiery rhetoric but tried to hew to President Trump’s agenda.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and Patricia Sulbarán
item.media:description: Venezuela’s interim president, Delcy Rodríguez, delivering a speech at the National Assembly in Caracas on Thursday.

item.title: The Nobel Peace Prize Medal Has Been Sold Before for Millions
item.description: The Nobel Committee has said the prize cannot be transferred, but it has been sold in a few auctions over the award’s history.
item.dc:creator: Pranav Baskar
item.media:description: Since the 1980s, the Nobel medal has been made with recycled gold.

item.title: Cuba Receives Remains of 32 Citizens Killed in U.S. Strikes in Venezuela
item.description: The Cubans had served as part of the security detail of Nicolás Maduro, Venezuela’s ousted president.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak
item.media:description: A motorcade transporting the Cuban‑flag‑draped urns of citizens killed in the U.S. strike in Venezuela earlier this month.

item.title: Cyberattack in Venezuela Demonstrated Precision of U.S. Capabilities
item.description: Lt. Gen. Joshua M. Rudd appeared before the Senate Armed Services Committee, which is weighing his nomination to lead the U.S. Cyber Command, but provided little new information about the operation.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Sunrise in Caracas on Jan. 3. Turning off the power in Caracas and interfering with radar allowed U.S. military helicopters to move into the country undetected on their mission to capture Nicolás Maduro.

item.title: Machado Presents Trump With Nobel Peace Prize
item.description: The Venezuelan opposition leader’s efforts to share her award with the U.S. president have shaken some Norwegians’ faith in their signature soft-power tool.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak and Henrik Pryser Libell
item.category: US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Venezuelan opposition politician María Corina Machado outside the U.S. Capitol in Washington on Thursday.

item.title: The U.S. Is Pressing Mexico to Allow U.S. Forces to Fight Cartels
item.description: The United States is escalating pressure on the Mexican government to permit the U.S. military to target fentanyl labs, according to American officials.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib, Julian E. Barnes, Eric Schmitt and Tyler Pager
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: White powder, purportedly finished fentanyl, sitting on a table in a makeshift lab operated by the Sinaloa cartel.

item.title: Venezuela Strongman and Maduro Ally, Diosdado Cabello, Faces an Uneasy Transition
item.description: Diosdado Cabello, Venezuela’s interior minister, is accused by U.S. prosecutors of drug trafficking and is linked to repression at home, yet remains a powerful figure.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Diosdado Cabello, Venezuela’s interior minister, welcoming a flight bringing Venezuelan migrants from Mexico last year.

item.title: James Luckey-Lange Among Americans Freed in Venezuela
item.description: James Luckey-Lange, 28, was released this week with several other U.S. citizens from the country’s notorious prison system after going missing in December, his family said.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Edward Wong

item.title: Venezuelan Immigrants Urge Appeals Court to Restore Deportation Protections
item.description: The Trump administration has ended Temporary Protected Status for about 600,000 Venezuelan immigrants, part of a broader effort to curb avenues for immigrants to remain in the United States.
item.dc:creator: Jazmine Ulloa
item.media:credit: Paul Ratje for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Border Servant Corps worker helped a Venezuelan woman who had just crossed the border at El Paso in 2024.

item.title: British Columbia Ends Program That Aimed to Curb Arrests of Drug Users
item.description: The three-year pilot program did not deliver the results hoped for, the health minister said. It had allowed drug users to avoid criminal charges for possessing small amounts of illegal substances.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Chad Hipolito/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Josie Osborne, the minister of health in British Columbia, announced on Wednesday that a drug decriminalization program would end on Jan. 31.

item.title: U.S. Races to Sell Venezuelan Oil, Transforming Ties With Former Foe
item.description: U.S. officials brokered the sale of hundreds of millions of dollars worth of Venezuelan oil to stabilize the country’s economy after capturing its president.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:description: An oil jack in Venezuela’s Orinoco Belt, the country’s main crude producing area.

item.title: Quebec Premier François Legault Resigns Ahead of Elections
item.description: Premier François Legault became Canada’s most popular provincial leader during the pandemic thanks to his reassuring, avuncular persona. But missteps sank his hopes for a third term.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:credit: Jacques Boissinot/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Premier François Legault of Quebec announcing his resignation on Wednesday.

item.title: Senate Republicans Block Effort to Check Trump’s War Powers in Venezuela
item.description: G.O.P. leaders succeeded in pressuring fellow senators who initially supported the measure that would have limited President Trump’s military authority in Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Robert Jimison and Megan Mineiro
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Senator Josh Hawley, Republican of Missouri, reversed himself on the war powers resolution, saying that Secretary of State Marco Rubio and President Trump convinced him that it was not needed.

item.title: Interviewing Colombia’s President, Before and After His Call With Trump
item.description: New York Times reporters waited more than eight hours to speak with President Gustavo Petro, who, as it turned out, had another important conversation in the works.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak and Annie Correal
item.media:credit: Nathalia Angarita for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Gustavo Petro of Colombia during his sit-down interview on Jan. 7 with The New York Times.

item.title: Venezuela Envoy to Visit U.S. for First Official Trip in Years
item.description: Félix Plasencia, an envoy of the interim government, will travel to the United States on the day the opposition leader María Corina Machado is to meet President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:description: Félix Plasencia, then Venezuela’s foreign minister, in Caracas, Venezuela, in 2022.

item.title: ‘We’re Not Stupid’: What Greenlanders Would Say to Trump
item.description: A visit to Greenland reveals a swirl of feelings as people nervously await talks with the Trump administration about the island’s future.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman and Maya Tekeli
item.media:description: Nuuk’s old harbor, Greenland, on Tuesday. People on the island have reacted with shock, anger, confusion and fear to President Trump’s interest in buying or taking over the territory.

item.title: Venezuela Announced the Release of Political Prisoners. Families Are Still Waiting.
item.description: Hundreds of families are hoping their loved ones will be freed by the Venezuelan government, which has said little about who would be released or when.
item.dc:creator: Isayen Herrera and Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Family members of political prisoners holding a vigil outside of the Rodeo I detention center last week in Guatire, Venezuela.

item.title: An Emboldened Trump Makes Big Bets in Venezuela, Iran and Beyond
item.description: President Trump has left himself plenty of room for maximal intervention. But there are a host of potential wild cards, each with risks for the president.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: President Trump has left himself plenty of room for maximal intervention, in Tehran, Caracas and elsewhere.

item.title: U.S. Refiners to Profit as Trump Asserts Control Over Venezuelan Oil
item.description: The companies that turn oil into gasoline and diesel are likely to benefit more, right away, than the businesses that pump oil out of the ground.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott
item.media:credit: Brandon Thibodeaux for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Valero Energy refinery in Houston. U.S. refining companies are poised to profit if more Venezuelan oil starts flowing to the United States.

item.title: If U.S. Were to Invade Greenland, ‘NATO Would Be Stuck’
item.description: The treaty that created NATO did not contemplate an attack by one ally on another. A seizure of Greenland by President Trump would test the endurance of the mutual-defense pact.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A frozen corner of the main fishing harbor in Nuuk, the capital of Greenland.
